Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it's just that they are now being marketed to "average people" without soldering abilities

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> The problem with FPGA is that hashrate is concentrated in the hands of a narrow circle of people. As a result, instead of 100 miners, we have 10 miners. Instead of 100 members of the community - 10 members who are much more interested in selling more mined coins than 100 members with fewer each

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Takoy_Nahal what about next year, when FPGAs that can mine dozens of coins cost less than 1 GPU ? Do your problems go away, if everybody can buy a FPGA for about the price of a good GPU?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> I calculated the cost difference between the Z9 and the RX 570 according to the daily profit on mining. The difference is reduced every week. It seems this is due to the fact that ASICS hashrate is growing much faster than the GPU. It is still necessary to take into account that in many countries, ASIC cannot be purchased from the site and it is necessary to use the services of intermediaries.
If you add the intermediary mark-up, the price / production difference in $ is even smaller.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> i hear talk of FPGA miners that plug into USB, they will be making cheaper ones, bringing down pricepoint

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> As I said before, I use the GPUs that I bought last year, and I plan when the bullish trend will be back to sell. At the moment I am a supporter of POS mining, as the most efficient and energy-efficient method of mining. I just wanted to say that the project first of all needs to attract a large mass of people.
The Verushash algorithm is ideal for this.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I am wondering, if you could buy FPGAs miner from various companies, and they were roughly the price of a good GPU, what is the argument against them? Why are they "bad"? It just raises the bar, if most people have access to them. That seems to be where we are headed. GPUs may soon become much more expensive than buying an FPGA, or at least similar prices

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I just keep remembering, being a GPU miner in the olden days of BTC, and hearing people say very very nasty things about people with *the nerve* to mine Bitcoin with a GPU!!!! Satoshi himself, in the whitepaper which cannot be questioned, did say "1 CPU 1 Vote"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> so GPUs are evil

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> that is why it's very hard for me to understand "ASICs are evil" or "FPGAs are evil"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> ask yourself, if as soon as you actually own some specific hardware, if it changes from being evil to just ordinary mining gear

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> that mining gets more efficient is not a surprise to anybody, at least it shouldnt be

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> expecting mining efficiency to stay constant is the same as expecting the price to be the exact same, regardless of external factors

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> VTC said they were ASIC resistant and due to this they became a lot more vulnerable to fpga mining

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> if they just accepted asic mining, then it wouldnt be the small circle of fpga miners (even smaller than ASIC miners) who are able to mine

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> and maybe the 51% attack would have been avoided

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> in any case, with nicehash able to aggregate massive hash power, it doesnt matter what algo you have if you dont have 51% defenses

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @jl777c VTC devs blamed the exchange, said they didn't listen to their confirmation "rules"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> 300 confs is crazy big amount

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> their new plan is to check the price to attack on Nicehash and dynamically change confirmations based on that

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I pointed out that NH was centralized and they all had a good laugh. They have no good solution

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> how can they get exchanges to adopt such a thing?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> i told them, they didn't listen

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> not that it would work anyway

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> they want to have confirmations count based on attack price

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> we had to implement dpowconfs to make it transparent for exchanges

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> i left the discord soon after that, i had said my peice

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> they are too good for dpowconfs, they will force a custom code change on every exchange. Great idea.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> they seriously want to monitor nicehash price and change confs required in realtime???

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> even if they can get exchanges to do that, they cant, it wont work

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> i was told that in #public-dev

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> siu and jorian were there

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> seems their devs are of the xvg level

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> they even gave me example PHP code on how to change the conf count based on price

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> i didn't know if they were trolling me

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> likely they were serious

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> they kept yelling "the holy 64 kmd masternodes" and after a while, it gets old. Also, one dude was seriously OFFENDED we tried to help. To propose a solution

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> but I learned a bit about VTC, and what some coins have issue with

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> they reject dPoW because they think it is centralized, but prefer to use nicehash prices with a fantasy scenario of exchanges changing confs required

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> it is best to not work with such projects. they will likely mess something up and then blame us for it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> there are plenty of other coins that see the value of DPoW

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> some communities are morally against some things, we can't change that

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> i never understood what VTC did that was unique, it seems it is their core devs commitment to "decentralization" which is basically whatever he says it is

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Hush community fits really well with KMD community, that is why DPoW is such a good fit for us

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> KMD is happy to work with other coin communities, I don't know any community that is more open. Some coins do not want to touch or look at or integrate with anything from other coins, oh well.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> the insanity is that 99.9% of coins are using the codebase of some other coin

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> not to mention crypto libs made by third parties

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> I believe I came the closest to writing an entire cryptocoin all by myself with iguana, but still it needed the secp256 lib along with bignum, sha256, and many other library functions

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> the idea is to use the best solution that is available to solve the problem at hand

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> anything else is suboptimal

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> I never claimed that ASIC is evil, I just wanted to convey two thoughts: Equihash was originally conceived as ASIC resistance, so many people liked the coins of this algorithm and saw it as a refuge. The second in my opinion CPU, POS, POW contributes to a wider involvement of people for the community. ASIC, FPGA,
masternodes are much more often concentrated in a narrow circle of people and do not cover the wider masses. I personally support POS mining as the most effective way to earn money and attract interest from the poorest to the richest.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> GPU will never die as CPU mining does not die. From a marketing point of view, each mining tool has its own audience and its own coins. If you chose a certain path - stick to it, as for example Monero (and its forks) successfully does it no matter what, turning the ASIC for Monero into nothing.
If you chose the ASIC path then you had to choose the scrypt, sha-256 algorithm

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> At this point, it seems that the only option is for Verus to change VerusHash slightly, and fpga people will just update their bitstream. It's not looking good for VerusHash + CPUs/GPUs
